Despite the romantic idea of being the hero in your own story, it’s highly unlikely you’ve found a pair of Hoffman lenses and are privy to a truth unseen by those around you.

Although I see the appeal of this movie, I wonder if it’s created more problems than it solves.

The descriptions of him beating up his girlfriend and slashing the throat of a disguised alien are visceral and make him an unsympathetic character, exactly the opposite of the charm that Roddy Piper has in the movie.

Here’s the thing: the movie “They Live” is based on a short story called “Eight O’Clock in the Morning” which is much more ambivalent about whether the protagonist is actually “awake” or whether he’s suffering from violent paranoid delusion.
It’s an appealing message, partly because it means we’re just victims of our lives, and don’t have to think too critically about our own role in our circumstance. “Take the red pill and wake up!”
…who don’t have our best interests at heart—the world isn’t as it seems. Be the hero and free the brainwashed masses, it suggests, and fight the invisible hand that controls us.

And we’ve all lost so much, in so many ways. But the virus will continue on, even if we get tired or angry or bored. We need to keep our focus where it belongs. The virus is the real enemy—never forget that.

I don’t think we should follow blindly, but I also try to be mindful of how many lives we’ve saved by the things we *have* been doing. We all want to save more lives, and keep life as normal as possible.

Unfortunately, hindsight is 20/20 and there are always things that could’ve happened differently, but we’re not always aware of the data or considerations going into some profoundly complex decision making.

I wonder if some of the frustration floating around now about the PHO might be similar—the virus isn’t visible and so eventually our frustration and anger relating to what the virus has taken from us is projected onto authority figures.

I’m actually amazed at how smoothly traffic is moving—the flashers are efficient! The potholes are bad though and getting worse with so much heavy traffic. 

Approaching Sunshine Valley, and I assume the mudslide. I’ve never seen Sumallo River this brown… or this high.
Was the Skagit River hungry for road snacks? Yes, yes it was. May I suggest corn nuts and not a half lane of highway next time? Single lane alternating.

I appreciate that almost no one is using the passing lanes, when available. Slow and steady.

@kelownagurl Hindsight is always 20/20, and it's easy to criticize. Governing is impossibly hard, which is why every single government has a shelf-life. I'll bet this one is pretty happy they got themselves an extended, solid mandate to weather the bumps of MULTIPLE SIMULTANEOUS CRISES.
@kelownagurl This has better be a wakeup call, though, to the @bcndp, that there's hard work to do to prioritize to further strengthen forecasting, communication and emergency response systems.

@kelownagurl Yes and no. These things take a HUGE amount of time to get studied, approved, etc and typically take more than a single government mandate to do. A government isn't usually going to get briefed on day one and start a thousand projects, because they're often ALL "urgent".

@kelownagurl I see both systemic failures here and successes, and lots of politics is being played, already, with blaming and back-slapping, depending on which "side" you're on. Our infrastructure needs to evolve. We need more responsive emergency systems, at a scale most didn't consider.

That's the whole point of population-level vaccination--not just to stop individual pieces of wood from burning, but to try and stop the fire completely, one wet piece of wood at a time.

Getting the wood wet still prevents it from catching fire in many cases, prevents it from spreading as far in most cases, and eventually the fire is going to burn itself out for lack of dry fuel or at least only smoulder where it can be contained.

…but even wet wood can still burn, especially if exposed to a large enough dose of fire. It's also possible for wood to get singed (catch COVID, but not have it fully engulf the wood) and then it might burn again.

I like analogies… they help organize our thinking towards salient details. Try this one on for size: 

Think of COVID like fire. It burns better and is more likely to spread in dry (unvaccinated) wood, over wet (vaccinated) wood…

Maybe I’m feeling a little mournful today as I watch the last leaves of the season fall off the trees here at work. Maybe it’s the psychic echoes of the big car accident last week. Whatever it is, it’s never bad to be reminded that our time here is finite and precious.

I spent seven years working in a building that was once Vancouver’s morgue (@policemuseum), offering insight into the modern rituals of death, at least in a city context. But rural death just hits different.

A few days ago, I made a massive pot of soup and several loves of bread for a family who had been keeping fire and were putting their loved one in the ground that day. I didn’t know them well enough to attend, but I did know they’d need food for the army of support they had.

Last spring, I hosted a small luncheon for the family of a lady I’d grown close to—she loved to come to my work and paint with her friends. But her cancer was aggressive, and she’d opted for medical assistance in dying. I was her last meal out. Next day, she was gone.

And in a community with a significant Indigenous population, there is also a week of keeping a fire burning for their departed loved ones, 24/7, before any church service or wake. A pause to mourn and reflect.
When someone dies in a small town, there are usually memorial posters up everywhere.
You hear more about the how, the why and the where and when. You experience the grief of others more directly, it’s not smudged into the anonymous daily blur of city living.

One of the things I didn’t expect when I moved to a small town was how to changes your relationship with death. Someone’s passing is felt more acutely when it affects many in your daily circle—reminiscences shared at work, at the grocery store, on the street.

In my own riding, I like all three larger party candidates as people. But to decide how to vote in this election is *hard*…

Greens: I know nothing about them and their current platform, apart from some amorphous internal strife. They genuinely want to address our most pressing big issues, but seem to have icky ideas on the little ones.

Cons: impressive discipline to stay as quiet and unthreatening as possible this campaign in the hopes that they slip in because people don’t notice them. Don’t like the right-wing populist stuff and they keep dangerous friends, but they also push back Lib ideas in necessary ways.

NDP: doesn’t spend enough time repudiating ideas on the right, instead getting into left-wing populist stuff. JS seems like a decent fellow and there are good things in the party platform, but they always come from a place that fails to recognize the real messiness of governing.

Libs: effective in the pandemic in many ways, but too quick to blame others for their own failures. JT has let his opponents define him, which is death in politics. He seemed to start with a strong team around him, but they seem to be coasting.

But man… confronted with this lady and her broken heart, I couldn’t stand as firmly on my principles as I would in almost any other situation. 

Does that make me part of the problem… or just human? <sigh>
I have plenty of strong opinions about following the rules and doing the right thing, even if they go far beyond the rules and guidelines. Because, of course, we’re all in this together…

“We all know what the rules are,” I say. “I miss my own parents, too,” I say. “Matters of the heart are tricky,” I say. But I can’t bring myself to dress her down, or give her hell for what’s an obviously bad idea. Her own son will do that.

I can tell that she knows it’s wrong, but it’s also obvious that her heart aches so badly. It’s clear that she’s asking me because she hopes I’ll give her implicit permission and the truth is, she kind of got it because I can’t help but be polite.

A random lady just approached me, at a gas station, to ask what I thought she should do… her son, who she’s not seen in a year, is just one town over… she desperately wants finish the drive and knock on his door. (They live in the same health region, at least.)
